fieldset.xf:hint:
A term or phrase representing the primary topic(s) on which a work is focused. The use of at least one subject element in a record is recommended. Enter as many specific terms as necessary to capture subject content, and be consistent in the formatting of subject terms.
Values for subject indicate what content is found within or represented by the work, and typically answer such questions as who, what, where, and when.
It is highly recommended to use of subject values from a controlled list and to designate this list in the authority attribute.
There are a number of different formats for Subjects. While it is allowed to place multiple values in a single Topic string, parsing subject terms into separate subelements is the preferred practice. If there are several topics, place each into it own field.
A Subject is basically composed of a Topic, a Geographic reference and a Temporal reference. All elements are optional, that is, one can have a Topic without any Geographic or Temporal reference, and one can have a Geographic reference without a Topic or a Temporal reference. To have a Temporal reference all by its own would be a little unusual, but if period labels are used, this might still be comprehensible. The Topic can be divided into different kinds: abstract Topic (simply called "Topics"), Name topics and Title topics. This means that a topic can be an abstract concept, the name of a person or institution or the name of a publication. These three address the "what" of a subject. When Name or Title is used, the full repetoire of elements used when cataloguing
The "where" of a subject can be expressed in a number of ways. "Geographic" simply contains the name of the place. "Hierarchical Geographic" gives a breakdown into a hiearchy of geographical division, from continent to area within a city. "Cartographic" identifies the place by means of coordinates. "Geographic Code" identifies the place by means of a code in an authority file. The recommendation is to use the simple "Geographic", linking this to the Getty TGN.
Compared to this, "Temporal" is simple, but time can be encoded in a number of different ways.

xf:select1.xf:label: Authority:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The name of the authoritative list for a controlled value is recorded here. An authority attribute may be used to indicate that a subject is controlled by a record in an authority file.

fieldset.xf:hint: Use this subelement to indicate any primary topical subjects that are not appropriate in the Geographic, Temporal, Title Information, or Name subelements. In general, abstract nouns should be used. While it is highly recommended that subject values be parsed into subelements, they may also be listed as a string, divided by e.g. a dash.

xf:input.xf:label: Topic:
xf:input.xf:hint: Use this subelement to indicate any primary topical subjects that are not appropriate in the Geographic, Temporal, Title Information, or Name subelements.

fieldset.xf:hint: Use this subelement for geographic subject terms that are not parsed within the Hierarchical Geographic element. If the geographic name is part of a corporate body (for example, United States. Senate), it is coded as Name, not Geographic.

xf:input.xf:label: Geographic:
xf:input.xf:hint: Use this subelement for geographic subject terms that are not parsed within the Hierarchical Geographic element.

fieldset.xf:hint: Use this subelement for chronological subject terms or temporal coverage. It may be expressed as a controlled subject term or as a structured date (e.g. "2010-08-06").

xf:select1.xf:label: Encoding:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Used to note the encoding followed in the date notation.

xf:select1.xf:label: Point:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Used to note whether the date noted is a start point or an end point. If no point attribute is specified, date is assumed to be a single date.

xf:input.xf:label: Temporal:
xf:input.xf:hint: Use this subelement for chronological subject terms or temporal coverage.

fieldset.xf:hint:
At least one Title inside a Title Information is required. Title Information can be repeated for alternative, translated, transliterated or uniform titles. These values are chosen in Type. For the basic Title Information entry, use the default value "Basic Title Information". If, in addition to the basic title, there is also an alternative, translated, transliterated or uniform title, add a Title Information and choose the relevant Type. Repeat Title Information as many times as necessary.
A Title Information consists of a Title and fields that relate to it. A Title may have a Subtitle, usually an expansion of the Title proper. If the Title begins with a word according to which it should not be sorted (such as "The" or "A" and the like), enter this word in Non Sort and remove it from Title. If a publication consists of several parts, parts that are either numbered or named, use Part Number and/or Part Name. A "History of Europe" may have several numbered part, such as "Part One. Ancient Greece." Enter "Part One" in Part Number and "Ancient Grecce" in Part Name.
When no title appears on the item being described, a title should be supplied by the cataloguer. Do not use brackets or other punctuation to indicate that the title has been supplied; instead, use the Display Label attribute to indicate that the title is supplied, by giving it the value "Supplied Title". A supplied title should be created in accordance with an established standard, and describe, as concisely as possible, the content of the resource in question. If no standards apply, consider carefully the expectations end users have for the naming of similar resources.
If an alternative, translated or transliterated title is recorded, choose the relevant Type for each separate Title Information.
If a uniform or abbreviated title is entered, choose the appropriate value in Type and note in which authority file the uniform or abbreviated title in Authority has been found. Authority files are only used in connection with uniform and abbreviated titles.
Record the language of the title information by choosing the Language used in the resource.

xf:select1.xf:label: Type:
xf:select1.xf:hint:
This attribute identifies what type of Title Information is recorded. The default is Basic Title Information. The following values may be used in addition to this: Abbreviated, Translated, Transliterated , Alternative, Uniform.
When an abbreviated title is present, an Authority must be chosen. An alternative title may be a parallel title found in the authoritative title information (in written works, typically the title page) or a title that does not occur in the authoritative title information, e.g. a title found on a cover. If the alternative title does not occur in the authoritative title information, indicate in Display Label where the information comes from (e.g., "Cover Title"). If the alternative title does occur in the authoritative title information, it is probably a translation (or a transliteration) of the main title information. If a translation or transliteration based on the evidence of the work being catalogued, choose "Alternative" for Type and note the language, transliteration and script of the title information, as appropriate.
A uniform title is a title that refers uniformly to a work that is known by several titles, e.g. the works of Shakespeare or the Bible. When a uniform title is present, an Authority for its selection must be chosen.
When title information is translated or transliterated by the cataloguer, choose the values "Translated" or "Transliterated" for Type and note the language, transliteration and script of the title information as appropriate.

xf:select1.xf:label: Authority:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The name of the authoritative list for the abbreviated title is recorded here.

xf:select1.xf:label: Authority:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The name of the authoritative list for the uniform title is recorded here.

xf:select1.xf:label: Language:
xf:select1.xf:hint:
The language used within Title Information is specified here. The most common languages have been moved to the top of the list.
The language used in the resource as a whole is given in Language Of Resource and may well be the same.

xf:select1.xf:label: Transliteration:
xf:select1.xf:hint: This attribute specifies the transliteration (transcription, romanisation) scheme used within Title Information. When specificing the transliteration used, also specify the language employed. There is at present no standard list of transliteration schemes available. If you wish to employ a transliteration on the scheme, please contact . In general, the Library of Congress transliteration schemes () should be used. If you follow a transliteration scheme authorised by , choose as the value and note the language from which the transliteration is made. The following transliteration schemes are authorised by : Chinese: pinyin Japanese: (modified) Hepburn Korean: Russian: Sanskrit: If you employ a different, but reccognised, transliteration scheme, you may have it added to the list.

xf:select1.xf:label: Script:
xf:select1.xf:hint: This attribute specifies the script used within individual elements. The use of Latin script is not noted. "Chinese" is "Han (Simplified Variant)" or "Han (Traditional Variant)". If the two variants are not considered, it is "Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja)", also used for Japanese, Korean and Vietnamese written in Chinese.

xf:input.xf:label: Display Label:
xf:input.xf:hint: This attribute is intended to be used when additional text associated with the title is needed for display. The Display Label attribute may be used whenever appropriate to indicate the preferred labeling when displayed. Appropriate cases include titles other than the primary title or subtitle. Include the text preferred and capitalisation, but do not include delimiters such as colons.

xf:input.xf:label: Non Sort:
xf:input.xf:hint: Non Sort contains characters, including initial articles (typically "A" and "The" in English), punctuation, and spaces that appear at the beginning of a title that should be ignored when indexing and sorting.

xf:input.xf:label: Title:
xf:input.xf:hint:
Title contains the core title of the resource catalogued.
At least one Title is required. When no title appears on the item being described, a title should be supplied.
Title includes all parts of a title that are not covered by Non Sort, Subtitle, Part Number and Part Name.
Dates may be recorded under Title or Subtitle only if they are part of the title. Publication dates are included under Origin Information.
For parallel titles, i.e., equivalent titles in different languages that have not been translated by the cataloguer, add a Title Information and enter the Title there with the Type attribute "Alternative" for each parallel title. Note the language, script and transliteration of each title.
For a title translated or transcribed by the cataloguer, add a Title Information and enter the Title there with the Type attribute "Translated" or "Transliterated" for each title. Note the language, script and transliteration of each title added in this way.
For abbreviated titles, add a Title Information block and enter the Title there with the Type attribute "Abbreviated" for each parallel title.
For uniform titles, i.e., titles with various renderings that are unified by an authority file, add a Title Information and enter the Title there with the Type attribute "Uniform". Under each uniform title, state the Authority according to which the uniform title has been selected.

xf:input.xf:label: Subtitle:
xf:input.xf:hint:
Subtitle is used to record a part of a title deemed secondary to the core title.
Use Subtitle whenever a subtitle is present, rather than including the subtitle in Title.
When using Subtitle, do not include punctuation intended to separate the title from the subtitle at the end of Title.
If more than two levels are in evidence in the whole title, i.e. if there is a sub-subtitle, include the sub-subtitle in Subtitle, with appropriate punctuation. Every part of the title that do not belong in Title, Part Number or Part Name, belong in Subtitle.

xf:input.xf:label: Part Number:
xf:input.xf:hint:
Part Number is used for a part or section number in a title.
A Part Number does not have to be a digit, i.e. "First Part" may be the contents of the Part Number field if this is how it occurs on the title page.
Part Number may describe the section of an digital object (for example, an episode number or an audio or video clip).
Use Part Number when a part number is present, rather than including the part number in the text of the Title.
When using Part Number, do not include punctuation at the end of the preceding element intended to separate the part number from previous parts of the title.

xf:input.xf:label: Part Name:
xf:input.xf:hint:
Part Name is used for a part or section name of a title. Use Part Name when a part name is present, rather than including the part name in the text of Title. Use Part Name to describe the section or division titles of a digital object (for example, a chapter title, episode name, or an audio or video clip).
If a resource has multiple parts, each with its own Part Name, the work should be catalogued in as many records as there are Part Names.
When representing the Part Name, do not include punctuation at the end of the preceding element intended to separate the part name from previous parts of the title.

fieldset.xf:hint:
Names contain the names of persons, organisations, or events (conferences, meetings, etc.) associated in some way with the resource catalogued.
Include as many Names blocks as needed.
In addition to describing creators, Names is used as a kind of Subject. For names used as subjects, see the Subjects tab.
For textual materials, include the names of all known authors, translators, compilers, and editors.
For images, include the name of the creator of the original intellectual content (photographer, painter, architect, etc.) and the name of anyone capturing that content in a new medium (for a photograph of a building, include both the architect and the photographer).
If no known person or organisation, etc. is known to be associated with the resource, or if the person or organisation etc. is anonymous, do not include "unknown," "anonymous," or similar annotations; rather, leave the Names block empty.

xf:select1.xf:label: Type:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The type attribute can take the following values: personal, corporate, conference. Use it to indicate whether the name is the name of a person, the name of a corporation or the name of a conference.

xf:select1.xf:label: Authority:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The name of an authoritative list for a controlled value in Name is recorded here. If you render the name as it occurs in the resource, you may leave the Authority attribute value blank. If you normalise the name, you should indicate according to which authority you are altering it. Use the value "Local" if a locally-developed name authority file has been used to catalogue the Name in question.

xf:select1.xf:label: Language:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Hint

xf:select1.xf:label: Script:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Use this to record the script in which the name occurs, if this is not Latin.

xf:select1.xf:label: Transliteration:
xf:select1.xf:hint: If the name is rendered in translietrated form, register the transliteration scheme followed here.

xf:select1.xf:label: Type:
xf:select1.xf:hint:
Name Part includes each part of the name. Parsing is used to indicate a date associated with the name, to parse the parts of a corporate name, or to parse parts of a personal name into family/surname and given name/forename. The parsing performed is indicated by the Type attribute. This attribute takes the following values: Date, Family, Given, Terms Of Address.
Date is used to parse dates that are not integral parts of a name. For, e.g. dates within a conference name, do not use this attribute to separate the date, since it is an integral part of the name string. The birthdate associated with a personal name, however, is not an integral part of the name, but added to distinguish the name from others, so it does include a separate Name Part with a Type of "Date". "Date" is generally not used when parsing the components of a corporate name.
"Family" is used for the family name or surname of a person.
"Given" is used for the given name or forename of a person.
"Terms Of Address" is used to record titles and enumeration associated with a name, such as "Jr.", "II", etc.
If you do not know how to break up a name or if a name is not constructed according to the family name/given name pattern, leave the Type of the Name Part blank.

xf:input.xf:label: Name Part:
xf:input.xf:hint: The name itself is always entered into a Name Part. See the hint above for futher explanation.

fieldset.xf:hint: This subelement includes a hierarchical form of a place name relating to the content of the resource that is both readable by humans and parsable by machines. This form can be applied to the degree of specificity that is known or relevant and used to generate browseable hierarchies even when values are specified to different levels. Explicit inclusion of the complete hierarchy is of potential benefit for automated consultation of a gazetteer to derive map coordinates or to support a map-based interface for searching by country or state. This subelement has no attributes.

xf:select1.xf:label: Continent:
xf:select1.xf:hint: Includes Asia, Africa, Europe, North America, South America.

xf:input.xf:label: Country:
xf:input.xf:hint: Name of a country, i.e. a political entity considered a country.

xf:input.xf:label: Province:
xf:input.xf:hint: Includes first order political divisions called provinces within a country, e.g. Canada.

xf:input.xf:label: Region:
xf:input.xf:hint: Includes regions that have status as a jurisdiction, usually incorporating more than one first level jurisdiction.

xf:input.xf:label: State:
xf:input.xf:hint: Includes first order political divisions called states within a country, e.g. in U.S., Argentina, Italy. Use also for France dÃ©partement.

xf:input.xf:label: Territory:
xf:input.xf:hint: Name of a geographical area belonging to or under the jurisdiction of a governmental authority.

xf:input.xf:label: County:
xf:input.xf:hint: Name of the largest local administrative unit in various countries, e.g. England.

xf:input.xf:label: City:
xf:input.xf:hint: Name of an inhabited place incorporated as a city, town, etc.

xf:input.xf:label: City Section:
xf:input.xf:hint: Name of a smaller unit within a populated place, e.g., neighborhoods, parks or streets.

xf:input.xf:label: Island:
xf:input.xf:hint: Name of a tract of land surrounded by water and smaller than a continent but is not itself a separate country.

xf:input.xf:label: Area:
xf:input.xf:hint: Name of a non-jurisdictional geographic entity.

xf:input.xf:label: Extraterrestrial Area:
xf:input.xf:hint: Name of any extraterrestrial entity or space, including solar systems, galaxies, star systems, and planets as well as geographic features of individual planets.

fieldset.xf:hint: Cartographics is a wrapper element that includes cartographic data indicating spatial coverage.

xf:input.xf:label: Coordinates:
xf:input.xf:hint: Coordinates contains a statement of coordinates covered by the resource. One or more statements may be supplied. If one is supplied, it is a point (i.e., a single location); if two, it is a line; if more than two, it is a n-sided polygon where n=number of coordinates assigned. No three points should be co-linear, and coordinates should be supplied in polygon-traversal order.

xf:input.xf:label: Scale:
xf:input.xf:hint: Scale provides a statement of scale. It may include any equivalency statements, vertical scales or vertical exaggeration statements for relief models and other three-dimensional items.

xf:input.xf:label: Projection:
xf:input.xf:hint: Projection provides a statement of projection.

fieldset.xf:hint: Geographic Code includes a geographic area code associated with a resource. A geographic code that represents the same entity as a term in Geographic is included within the same Subject element.

xf:select1.xf:label: Authority:
xf:select1.xf:hint: The name of the authoritative list for a controlled value is recorded here.

xf:input.xf:label: Geographic Code:
xf:input.xf:hint: Geographic Code includes a geographic area code associated with a resource. A geographic code that represents the same entity as a term in Geographic is included within the same Subject element.

fieldset.xf:hint: Occupation includes a term that is descriptive of the occupation reflected in the contents of the described materials. It is not used to list the occupations of the creators of the described materials, unless those occupations are significantly reflected in the materials themselves or bear some relationship to the materials.
